ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

LEFT TURN ON RED SCHEME

(Progress)



    1. Mr Lew Syn Pau asked the Minister for Communications (a) how has the pilot project allowing traffic to turn left on red at some of the traffic lights been progressing; and (b) whether his Ministry will consider extending it to more or all traffic lights.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications (Dr Yaacob Ibrahim) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Left Turn On Red scheme has been successful in reducing the delay of left-turning traffic at the junctions where it is implemented. On average, more than half of these vehicles are able to clear the junction during the red light period. The scheme has been extended to a total of 58 locations island-wide.

Column: 1488



    The scheme requires motorists to come to a complete stop to look out for any pedestrian or vehicle before proceeding with the left turn. However, there have been instances where motorists failed to do so. I would like to take this opportunity to remind motorists to take due care and make the left turn on red only when it is safe to do so. LTA will monitor the practices of motorists in this regard before extending the scheme to other junctions.

COMMITTEE ON SINGAPORE'S COMPETITIVENESS


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [23rd November, 1998],

    "That this House endorses the strategies and policies set out in the Report of the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness, contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1998, as the basis for strengthening Singapore's competitiveness.". - [Minister for Trade and Industry].

    Question again proposed.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure for the last few days, you have listened to many colourful speeches. There will be 18 more after me and I hope you will be able to have a keen ear in terms of what would be expressed. I am sure, Mr Speaker, you will be able to write a thesis after that!

    Sir, I would like, first of all, to commend the members of the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness for mapping out a very good comprehensive strategy to meet Singapore's economic and future challenges. The Report sets out the direction and we have got various inputs. The members have indeed done a significant job in compiling a very comprehensive report.

    What I would like to also commend is the very effective and immediate measures taken by the Government to implement with immediate effect the cost cutting measures to boost our competitiveness. The measures are very significant and I hope all Singaporeans will rally behind the Government to see how they can support a plan which can be implemented to help Singapore to be viable and to be able to meet the more serious challenges ahead.

Column: 1489



    Sir, having a plan is not sufficient but I think we will have to examine why Singapore is one of the countries in Asia that is not seriously affected and dislocated by economic problems, unlike many other places. I think most Singaporeans tend to take this for granted, that things are going well and therefore there are less issues that we are challenged with. The Government is able to look after these issues. They are capable people to think of solutions. I feel this is not realistic, Sir. It is very important that we go behind the reasons as to what makes Singapore less affected by the current economic problems. This analysis is very important so that we can understand the fundamentals that can be challenged in future.

    Sir, I would like, at the outset, to state that political stability is one of the cornerstones in our capacity to remain afloat, and I see that we have also taken this for granted. We should look at the political mess in many of the countries around the region and the world. There are many so-called democracies which have very good plans, good ideas, but many of these have not been implemented. Many people in these countries are affected and many of them have no capacity or ability to influence such decisions that have been made, and many of these people have suffered grave economic injustices and grave problems and regression in terms of their standard of living. And all these are issues that we need to examine and appreciate in the context of why we have been able to manage effectively.

    Sir, what becomes very important when we are faced with a recession is our capacity to maintain good political stability and cohesion. When resources are limited, there is always competition for resources, and the less able will not be able to get the kind of resources which they require for their living. So what is most important in this respect is that I would like to urge employers to seriously examine the approaches they adopt in the employment of workers, in ensuring that their practices are not discriminatory in terms of race, language and religion. This is very important in the context of

Column: 1490

Singapore, because we are a multi-racial society. If we believe in the principle of meritocracy, then I think employers, in times of recession and economic problems, must be very objective to ensure that we deal with the problems of retrenchment and unemployment on the basis of merit and objectivity. This is very important. Otherwise, we will upset the equilibrium of the multi-racial society that we live in.

    Secondly, we also have to look at the whole issue about good leadership in social institutions. Unless and until we ensure that we have good people managing our various social institutions, we may not be able to discharge the kind of plans that we have. And what is important for us Singaporeans is that we have to ensure that we continue to have people with good leadership, good personal integrity and honesty to manage various social institutions. Because these very social institutions, by their nature, are institutions that will make our society viable. It is not sufficient to say that we need good social institutions, but it is important to ensure that we need to nurture and have good people who can manage these institutions. We should induct good people into these institutions so that they can continue to manage them effectively in the interest of the majority.

    Finally, we also need to look at a good plan to manage issues ahead. And the CSC Report is an effective plan in that we have been able to mobilise various people to work on it and come up with various ideas that we can marshal and, hopefully, with the implementation of these ideas, we will be able to make a further stride in dealing with the economic problems that we face. So good plans do require good people and good political context to manage and implement them. Without these precursors, the best ideas that we have will not see any fruition and it will not have any impact on the social lives and to solve various social problems that we may face in our society.

    Sir, what we need to look at is to see how the CSC Report could address a number of issues which have been left out. I foresee that the issue of prolonged

Column: 1491

unemployment needs to be re-examined very closely, because we have depended on full employment as a form of social security. This is good as long as full employment lasts, but we never know through prolonged recessions, what impact this would have on people who are less skilled, semi-skilled and others who may not be able to find themselves employable. We need to examine the assumptions of full employment very critically, and in future, if we run into a prolonged recession, there is a need to assess how people who cannot be employed for a long time would still have a way to manage their lives.

    Sir, prolonged unemployment is one of the issues that we need to examine and the CSC has not examined this issue fully. We have to look at what can be done, particularly for older workers who would remain unemployable for a long time. We may argue that there are retraining funds available to upgrade them, that special funds would be available and set aside for their training, but I think the issue at hand is their employability. In some circumstances, it may not be possible for them to find employment itself because work institutions may not necessarily take them. I feel that there is a need to look at either the trade union level where some funds are set aside to deal with the upgrading of these workers in order to solve their long-term employment needs and problems.

    The other issue the CSC Report has not addressed is the challenge of the older workforce. This would be one of the more serious challenges that we are likely to face in the next decade. And with an older workforce, would we remain competitive? This is a question we need to examine. We may not become competitive, provided they have the capacity to be trained and upgraded and to move into job areas which would deal with information technology. So I feel that with a declining population which is below replacement, the issue will become very grave in the near future, and we have to look at how we can maintain a more robust workforce. This means that we have to recruit more

Column: 1492

talents, more semi-skilled and skilled workers to enter our workforce. I see this issue requires to be studied more closely.

    I am glad that the Government has set up the STAR Committee to look at these issues and, hopefully, it will solve some of the problems of the greying of our workforce.

    I would like to give some comments on the Government measures to reduce costs which have been announced yesterday. The measures are comprehensive and will help to stimulate our economy. The measures are realistic because they are implementable and some of them, in fact, have taken immediate effect. Hopefully, with the implementation of these measures we will be able to become more viable. What is most important and gratifying to note is that the direction of the cost-cutting measures which are to be implemented works on the principle of shared burden. I am glad that the cost-cutting measures work on the basis of those who can carry a heavier burden than those who cannot. This is a very good principle and I must applaud the Government for the effort in this direction, because for those who are unable to do so they do sacrifice, but they do sacrifice a little. This, at all costs, will enhance our ownership to the problem. We will be able to promote the sense of commitment to the various issues that we face. This in itself is very important. People feel that they can work towards a common cause and we are all sharing a common purpose and a common destiny, and we all believe that we want to make Singapore viable. Therefore, the question of ownership to these issues that we face has been reinforced.

    What I would like to urge is that we should have been a bit more generous with the lower income group. The rebates that have been granted by the Government provide an extension for a further period of time in their relief. But we could have been more generous in increasing the amount of S&C charges and PUB rates. That would have relieved further some of their burdens because many of them are unskilled and low income workers. They will face the greatest

Column: 1493

impact in terms of the capacity to manage their lives. It is desirable and our responsibility to see that we can do much more than what we have given to them.

    The second area which seems to invite attention is the levy. Many working mothers are most disappointed that they have not been given a reduction. All other companies that are employing foreign workers have been given a reduction. I think working mothers employing domestic maids should deserve attention because many of them are working hard in terms of helping to develop our economy and making Singapore viable. I do not see any reason why their case could not be considered.

    A very small proportion of working mothers benefit from the tax set-off. A large proportion of them are not benefiting from the tax set-off measures. I think it is not equitable in the sense that we have over the years increased the levy, but when all other revenues are being reviewed, they should in fact be given an opportunity to benefit from the reduction. In that respect, the argument that we want to dampen the demand for more of them to employ maids should be re-examined. I do not think the reason is strong enough to support the argument that no reduction has been considered for them. The issue is that many of them are in the middle class group, which I would call the "sandwiched" families. I feel that they should be considered. This is no real logical reason that I can gather that they should not be given due consideration for reduction of maid levy. There is a very large sector that would be affected in these trying times. I hope that their case could be reconsidered by the Minister for Manpower.

    Sir, in the final analysis, the social and economic crisis that we are all facing is our problem. It is important that we have to work together to fix it. Unless we can rally around to work together and find new creative ways, new approaches and new solutions to all these issues, we would not be able to tackle the problem as we hope to do so. So it is very important for us as Singaporeans to

Column: 1494

commit ourselves to working together. I am sure that all Singaporeans will rally behind the Government to see what we can do in our own ways. Whether big or small, we are all to be counted. Like what our Mr Deputy Speaker has said, small is beautiful. It is not just beautiful, but we are a people of mettle who can withstand and be counted as Singaporeans. I hope we can come together and find ways to weather the storm ahead. By doing so, we will keep ourselves afloat.

    Mr Simon S. C. Tay (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate on the motion.

    Much has been clarified by DPM Lee's response to the CSC Report yesterday. What the Government will do now, very shortly, is quite clear. Other points, however, remain for consideration - especially with regard to the medium to longer term view, but also on the possible effects of what Government will do.

    This is necessary because, as DPM reminded us, competitiveness is much more than cost-cutting. It is not a single attribute, but a combination of different elements. It is not only a question of economics or infrastructure, but it has human dimensions, such as education, skill and know-how, the flexibility of our system and the quality of life and the environment in our city. Competitiveness is not an absolute characteristic but a comparative one.

    In this debate, one detail will tend to dominate discussion, whether in this House or in the coffeeshops. This is the CPF and wage cut. The cut will touch us all. It is here and now, whereas many of the recommendations of the Report are for the longer term, and therefore more abstract.

    In this context, the CPF cut and wage cut may seem like a magic bullet. I doubt this is the intention and I am sure it will not be the effect. I am glad therefore that DPM Lee has put the cut and other cost-cutting measures in proper perspective. They give our companies breathing space, but only a regional and global recovery will ensure our future growth and development.

Column: 1495



    As such, in making my comments on the Report, I wish to focus on three main areas. Two are more immediate, while the third is for the medium to longer term.

    First, the effect of the cut: can it have unintended consequences? Second, the question of equity: how are the sacrifices distributed? Third, other concerns: what else do we need to do to complement the strategies in the Report for increasing competitiveness?

    The cut to wages will make people feel poorer. They would be even more reluctant to spend. Domestic demand may well go down. When our shops are empty, or filled only with window-shoppers, our business confidence will be affected. As such, there is a danger of a deflationary spiral.

    Not so long ago, our Senior Minister Lee warned against us over-reacting to the crisis by saving too much and cutting all our expenditure. In the same vein, at the off-Budget measures, a number of us called for greater efforts to stimulate demand. The cut to wages does the opposite. It is akin to an austerity measure for every citizen and wage earner. Even the IMF is now re-thinking of austerity measures.

    Economists tell us that Singapore depends two-thirds on external demand and only one-third on local demand. Therefore, they do not advise pump-priming. But even so, it seems to me that many small businesses depend largely or almost wholly on domestic demand - our shops in HDB estates and Orchard Road, our hairdressers and barbers, our professionals and car mechanics, our restaurants and food courts. As such, while the absolute effect may be one-third, it can spread across many sectors and many people and smaller businesses. If so, pump-priming our domestic demand will not help a large amount, but it can help quite a number of people. I would like the Minister's clarification on this point.

    We should act to keep people in our shopping centres and restaurants. We should act to keep a bounce in their step. We should keep Singapore a city with a

Column: 1496

buzz, confident that we will continue to be a centre of opportunity. I believe this proposed cut to wages may unintentionally do the opposite.

    It is not a question of "either or". We can do both. We can have the cuts to wages as well as a package to stimulate demand. We can lower cost of living or income tax through rebates. Lowering the cost of living in tandem with lower wages will lessen the pain people will feel. It will leave some spare cash in their pockets. This would feel good for the people and be good for the economy.

    The second unintended consequence of the cut that I fear may be our ability to attract and retain talent. Much attention has been given to the cost of manufacturing as compared to other countries in the region. But the Report itself calls for services to be a twin engine of growth. For services, other comparisons may be more appropriate. It is common talk that wages are higher in Hong Kong for some professionals, that the maximum on personal income tax is lower, and the corporate tax is lower. For research and development, another area that the Report recommends, there are other comparisons.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether Singapore is competing with the right countries for the right kinds of jobs and the right sectors. Our competitive position should take into account not only the economy as a whole, but the benefit of individuals living here. After all, it is not only investments that can move from one country to another, but also people. Therefore, it is my concern that with the cut, our ability to attract foreign talents here, which the Report calls for, will be unintentionally eroded. Worse, our ability to retain our existing talents may also weaken. We need to have talented and knowledgeable professionals, for these would be the foundation of a knowledge-based economy, and this will mean paying them world class wages.

    Let me turn to the second question of equity. Many are concerned about how the cuts and sacrifices are distributed. The statistics show that Government charges are smaller than the wage component,

Column: 1497

only some 10%. But perceptions differ. The old joke is that the PAP Government means Pay-And-Pay. This demonstrates the strength of that perception. Unless we deal with this perception, people will not willingly accept their share of the sacrifice. Instead, there may be a palpable resentment among some sectors about what they see, rightly or wrongly, as an iron rice bowl in the civil service and in Government.

    How do we tackle this perception? Ideally, we need institutionalised monitoring. Unlike the wage cut, there is less immediate impact from other cost-saving measures. This is particularly where measures are given indirectly. For example, where relief is given to landlords, we should know how much of this is eventually passed on to the tenants and others.

    Second, we need to check Government influence on costs. Many others have spoken about GST, maid levy, ERP, etc. I will not add to the wish list, since all the goodies we are going to get have already been handed out by DPM Lee. I may want to raise more general concerns. It is a good and timely move that JTC and HDB will re-look at industrial land costs. But what about other types of land, such as offices, retail and even residential property costs? We should benchmark all these against global competition, of course accepting our constraints. Other areas the Government must look into are telecommunications and electricity. Monopolies always have the temptation to extract the maximum amount from their captive audience. We are opening up these sectors eventually to competition. DPM Lee said yesterday, as regards SingTel, Government must honour its commitment for its monopoly licence. Fair enough. But until the day the competition comes, the regulation of these monopolies must serve to bring the costs to competitive levels. This, in the longer run, is for the good of these companies themselves if they are truly to be world class companies, as the Report aspires to.

Column: 1498



    I can make a more general point from this. How do we grow the world class companies? Our strategy cannot be to grant GLCs or any one else fat monopolies in Singapore, so that they can extract excessive profits here, and then venture overseas with deep pockets drawn from our money. We must ask the companies that wish to be world class to be lean and competitive, so that both their operations here and abroad are world class and give value for money.

    A third point is about Government statutory boards. I understand some statutory boards are in the habit of running up surpluses and yesterday I asked DPM Lee if these could be reviewed and cut. He explained that some statutory boards, like the JTC, must make surpluses because they need to get the best value for state assets that they alienate. I agree with him. But there are other boards that are different, and I think DPM also recognised this. I would ask that for such different statutory boards, the surpluses be reviewed. This is particularly for those who are supposed to facilitate business. For such business facilitation, surpluses do not always mean efficiency. Rather, the surpluses may represent costs extracted from businesses and individuals who have little choice but to pay the sums charged. For Government to be a truly good business facilitator, the policy should prefer cost recovery, rather than generating surpluses. We need to ensure that our Government agencies are benchmarked to the best practices. I agree with that. But Government agencies need to add value, not add costs.

    My last point on equity concerns the wage cut taken by our political leaders and top civil servants. There is a joke about political leadership and sacrifice. There is a plane with three politicians on board - Gandhi, Churchill and a third leader, Mr X. There are also a number of ordinary citizens on board. The plane is coming to a range of very high mountains, but the plane is struggling to climb high enough to pass safely. The pilot informs everyone that they may crash unless the load is lightened. They dump all the bags and cargo, but the plane is still too heavy.

Column: 1499



    In this crisis, Gandhi opens the airplane door, shouts, "For My People" and jumps out. With his sacrifice, the plane lightens a bit and climbs a little. But not enough. So, Churchill looks around and goes to the door. He shouts, "For My People" and jumps out. Again, the plane climbs, but still it is not enough. Finally, there is only the third leader and a number of ordinary citizens. The third leader goes to the door, opens it, shouts, "For My People" and throws all the ordinary citizens out.

    DPM Lee announced yesterday a 10% cut. I think that this is enough to show that Singapore does not have leaders like the third man in the joke. Still, many will ask, "Is 10% enough?" Percentages do matter and the public will judge for themselves. What I want to ask is more a question of the system itself. Is the system we have of fixing ministerial salaries working? I ask this bearing in mind that this is the second year running in which we have departed from the system. DPM Lee yesterday suggested that it was a problem of time lag. If so, I suppose we can fix by using more "real time" information about wages. But I would like the Government to consider an entire re-thinking of the system. Perhaps instead of pegging to a handful, an elite, should the approach be to broad band? This could be to a larger percentile of wage earners and it could well be more robust and politically acceptable.

    Having outlined my concerns with unintended consequences and equity, let me turn finally to other concerns. I wish to outline three concerns that, in my opinion, must be allied to the question of competitiveness.

    The first is to improve on natural resource efficiency. Sir, an important strategy in competitiveness is to be watchful over resource input. If you can produce more from less, you are more efficient, productive and competitive. This is particularly true when you do not own or have automatic and guaranteed access to those inputs and resources. There are sound reasons to be watchful over the use of natural resources in Singapore, such as electricity and, especially, water.

Column: 1500

The Report mentions both. The Report sees water and electricity as utilities that must be optimally managed.

    For water, the Report calls for Government incentives to be publicised. As regards electricity, the Report addresses the question of charges for stand-by purposes. For water, there are a few other strategies mentioned such as reducing wastage. But more can and should be done.

    While we can better publicise existing incentives, we may actually need to have better incentives to publicise. We also need to re-look at the policy of pushing up the price. Price can encourage greater efficiencies but only if it is undertaken in a context that increases awareness and capacity, and encourages innovation and investment. Otherwise, a price increase on its own simply leads to a price increase, and that will diminish competitiveness.

    The same is true of electricity. The cost is of real concern to businesses and households alike. This is especially given the eventual privatisation of Singapore Power. With privatisation, there may come a need to increase profits. If profits are tied solely to the selling of electricity, then there is no incentive for Singapore Power or any other supplier to be concerned about efficiency, productivity and competitiveness. It will simply try to sell more power for more money and profit. This will lead to a less competitive Singapore.

    Sir, there are many reasons to embrace policies that will encourage greater efficiency in the use of natural resources. Part of these reasons are environmental. But part of the reasons are also economic. Using off-the-shelf technology, some companies are now reporting that they have achieved what they call, "Factor Four", that is, they double income, while halving resource use. These private sector innovations need to be studied and understood. They can then serve as best practices that we should encourage others to adopt.

    The Government has an inter-agency committee to examine energy use in Singapore. I hope that they will have one

Column: 1501

on water. And I hope that the Government will task this agency to look particularly at the question of competitiveness and efficiency.

    The second thing that we need to ally competitiveness to is to increase our cooperation. The thrust of the Report is on Singapore's internal factors of competitiveness. We must not forget, however, the Report is coming amidst a crisis of the region. In fact, it is this regional dimension that has delayed the Report and forced it to focus on reducing costs vis-a-vis other countries. While it is Singapore's right to cut costs, we must guard against an intended perception. This is that we are trying to out-compete other countries in a negative manner. That is to say, we are cutting costs, so that we will steal investments from our neighbours and force them to lower their costs, or to devalue their currencies again.

    As DPM Lee has said, we are facing the toughest crisis since independence. So it is important that we do the right things and send the right message to the investors and stay on top of the problem.

    I am very happy that the Government has accepted the Report and all the key recommendations. In fact, the package of short-term measures that the Government has announced exceeds the expectations and the quantum is $10.5 billion, which is more than the figure of $10 billion that the CSC recommended. I think the feedback from the ground is that people are generally quite happy, including those who have been critical in the past, because they did not know what were the details and because there was perhaps insufficient explanations at that time.

Column: 1612



    Looking at the feedback, in fact, there was hardly any dissenting voice. One criticism that came to mind is the one by Mr Peh Chin Hua, that the quality of the paper was too good. If that is all, then I think we are on the right track.

    DPM Lee explained yesterday why we are taking this package of measures and why our position seems to have changed from February when we were still thinking that we could register maybe between 2.5% and 4.5% growth this year. He has explained that the whole world has changed. In fact, just a few weeks ago, people were worried that there could be a global economic melt-down. Because of the measures taken by the Federal Reserve in cutting the interest rate and that the IMF package is now being put together for Brazil, people are now breathing more easily. But I do not think we are out of the woods yet. So we need to do our best.

    Several Members have asked how we arrived at this figure of 15% cut in wage cost, whether it was based on hard numbers, political bargaining or judgment. The truthful answer is that this is a gut feel. It is based on our best judgment of the situation, based on data that is available and also on the understanding of the overall economic situation and the competition that we are facing.

    Naturally, those companies which are now faced with a sharp fall in demand from the region, and these are mostly local companies, are the ones which are most severely affected. As Dr Wang Kai Yuen has mentioned, the response that he got fell into two groups: the local firms which are mainly directed at the domestic market and the regional market. They are the ones asking for more measures because their demand has fallen off and they are faced with cash flow problems and they need more help. So they are the ones who are probably asking for the 20%-30% cut in their cost. On the other hand, some of the multi-nationals who are here are in fact very pleased that we have been able to do this. And Singapore is probably the only country in the world that has been able to mobilise everybody, the masses, through our trade unions,

Column: 1613

with our strong tripartite cooperation, and cut wages voluntarily, including the CPF. So this is a strong message that we are sending to investors, that Singapore is a different kind of country. We face up to the problems together, and we are determined to work together as a team to overcome the crisis.

    I met somebody from one of the top multi-national companies just a couple of weeks ago, and it was his first time in Singapore. He is from one of the top 500 companies in the world. He was utterly impressed and he said, "It is fantastic, you know. You have this Singapore Inc. approach." So I explained to him our measures and so on. I hope at the end of the day, he is going to put in more investments into Singapore. In fact, his question was: where are the workers? So I told him that we now have a relatively high unemployment rate and we intend to allow more foreign workers in, if necessary, and we are upgrading the industry all the time. For projects that we want, like this particular project which is in the computer area, we would try and free up the market and allow in more workers. So, as I said, I hope we will get some investments from that company.

    So the MNCs which have links with the region, which have, for example, subsidiary companies in Batam, and they are able to continue operating, they are less affected by the financial crisis. These companies are able to take advantage of the lower cost as a result of the devaluation of currencies, and they are happy. There are also other sectors like the shipyards which are doing all right because their costs are local and their revenues are in US dollars. So they find that they are now more competitive because they are competing with Middle-east yards and the currencies of the Middle-east are still strong.

    But, having said all that, I think the general feeling of the Ministry and our statutory boards is that we have lost competitiveness. The key figure that stands out is this loss of market share in the US. As I mentioned in my speech,

Column: 1614

kicking off this debate, our share of exports of electronics to the US has fallen by about two percentage points, from 9.3% to 7.3%, over a period of only 1 1/2 years or so. So that is very worrying for us because electronics form a very major sector of our economy, especially in the manufacturing sector, and they employ many workers. For the exports of non-oil manufactured products, of that figure, more than 60% are electronics. So you must be able to compete in that area.

    Looking at the figures, we have seen increases in market share from countries like Mexico, because of the NAFTA factor, from the Philippines, even from the PRC, even though they have not devalued their renminbi. It shows how competitive their costs are. In the case of the Philippines, they were under the IMF regime until recently. They have not had the excesses of the other neighbouring countries. So their economy is still functioning and I believe they are now very attractive to quite a number of investors. We see, for example, that Japanese companies are going there to manufacture disk drives, and they will offer stiff competition to us here. Most of our disk drive manufacturers are from the US and we are one of the biggest manufacturers in the world.

    So the feeling is that we have a gap over them in terms of capability, in terms of supporting industries, in terms of efficiency, but the gap is narrowing. We have to cut our costs. Basically, the decision is that this time round, we must do a re-calibration of our costs downwards - wage costs and other cost factors - and especially the land cost factor. Because the way the property market has been booming, it causes a lot of ripple effects, not only in terms of the market rates that the Government will have to try and peg for our industrial land but also in terms of the other effects, the way they work through the system, since land cost is a factor in every area, whether it is transportation or utility, or what-have-you.

    The assessment is that we do have to do a re-calibration, and that is why we came up with this figure. I think 15% is about right, not too much, not too little. Of course, we only know when we

Column: 1615

implement and we see what is the outcome. And if we have to do more, then we must do more. But if we do better than expected, then there could be corrections, there will be better bonus for employees and so forth. Basically, this cut of 15% of wage cost will bring us back to the level of 1994, and at that situation we were still very competitive. In fact, the economy then was growing close to 10% rate and the worry was that the labour market was getting too tight.

    The other way to look at this is that in 1985, when we had a similar recession and the GDP declined by about 2%, the CPF was cut by 15 percentage points, and that is equivalent to 12% of wage cost. This time round, the assessment is that the crisis is more severe because it is a world-wide problem now. So we have to take more drastic measures. If you look at the currency values too, the neighbouring currencies have depreciated by about 20% to 30% between 1st July last year and the latest figure, as compared to Singapore of about 12%. The currencies have recovered recently but we still have this gap over the neighbouring countries of about 15% or so.

    I hope I have given Members some idea of how we sort of did a gut feel, assessed the situation, and came out with this figure. We do not want to overdo it because it is a balance. If we overdo it, then people become very depressed and very pessimistic, and this could also dampen the demand in Singapore.

    Coming back to this point about the printing cost being too expensive, I was thinking, when I listened to the Member, that if we had spent less money on poorer quality paper, it would have meant less business for the printers. So it is a balance. Do you want to save cost or do you want to stimulate the economy? So we have to strike a balance here.

    Having said that, it is true that this $7 billion cut of wage cost may have some dampening effect on the economy. Of that, about $4 billion will be CPF. So there is no withdrawal of funds from the economy. But the balance could result in some withdrawal of funds. So I hope the

Column: 1616

Minister for Finance will consider this factor and bring forward some stimulatory projects in the new budget and go for a bigger budget deficit, so that we will be able to keep the economy going. The world-wide signal now is that it is time to reflate, but at the same time, we must be able to compete.

    There was a criticism from quite a few Members that these measures came too late. I have to answer this criticism because I have been very involved in the whole process. If Members may recollect, the Prime Minister said, as far back as November 1996, that he felt that our costs were getting out of line. Therefore, he was suggesting that we should have a committee to review the cost situation. And that is how the CSC came to be formed in May. We could have formed it earlier but, of course, we had elections and all the process that we had to go through. So this Committee was formed in May. And when we first started, all of us were looking way ahead. The economy was booming away, labour was tight, turnover was high, job-hopping was a problem. But when this crisis came in July, the whole situation changed. Now the worry is about unemployment rather than job-hopping.

    If you cast your mind back, at that time, the whole situation was in turmoil. The currency market and the stock market were very volatile. Everybody was very careful and anxious not to upset the market. You do not want to send the wrong signal and say, "Oh, things are going to be terrible!" Because then the market would really go down and it would be a self-fulfilling affair. So when we came out with figures on GDP projections, we tended to be careful, to be realistic, but not overly pessimistic. So, at that time, we felt that we might still be able, with our momentum of growth from past years, to make maybe 3% growth. So the package of measures were tailored for that situation. It was kind of a measured approach. On hindsight, I still think that was the best way to do it. Now that we are convinced that the storm is really on us and it is a very serious problem, our costs are really out of line, we have come out with a very

Column: 1617

big package of measures. And we still have reserves left, in case we have to do some more because the crisis is not over yet.

    Members mentioned the problem of liquidity. The feeling here is that, generally, there has been no problem of liquidity squeeze. I think DPM Lee, in some answers to oral questions, has explained that, in fact, the bank lending has continued to grow, although at a slower rate. The problem has been that the banks are now naturally more cautious, and rightly so, because some of them are so exposed in the region.

    That is why we have liberalised the Local Enterprise Finance Scheme, and I am glad to report that in terms of the short-term lending for export factoring, for working capital, the demand and the quantum of loans have really gone up. But in terms of loans for fixed assets, naturally companies are cautious. So the quantum has not gone up that much. The difficulty here is that we do not want to have a situation where our civil servants try and second-guess the bankers. The bankers assess the applications and they decide whether they are worth supporting or not supporting. As it is, we are sharing half the risk, and we are giving the entire spread of 2 1/4% on both the Government's share as well as their share entirely to the banks. That means they are earning a spread of about 4 1/2% on their loans. It is, I think, adequate for the purpose. But they have to assess whether it is worth their while and safe for them to lend. In cases where the borrowers feel that they deserve something better, they can go and see PSB, and then PSB can perhaps talk to the banks and discuss and see whether their assessment is correct. At the end of the day, the decision must be made by the banks. Having said that, we are open to suggestions. We are studying this all the time. If we can liberalise this further in a safe way and extend this scheme to more sectors, we will be happy to do so.

    There has also been concern for the retail sector, the sharp decline in demand

Column: 1618

as a result of the fall in tourist arrivals and the reduction in local spending. Here, I think it is important for us to go out and get more business. A short while ago, I was just at a function to present the Tourism Awards and I announced that the Singapore Tourism Board would be spending $30 million more next year in its marketing efforts. This will be on top of the usual $80 million per year that they spend on marketing. So it is an increase of 40%. This will tie in with the new programme they have to launch to welcome the new millennium. And I hope, with this effort, we will be able to increase our share of the tourism market.

    The key thing here is that it is not enough just to cut cost. We must all go out and try and get more business through STB, the Trade Development Board and EDB, and they are all going to work that much harder to try and get business for Singapore.

    Again, Members have spoken eloquently about the needs of the individuals. I think this is very important. We not only must ensure that our costs are competitive but also that the needs of individuals who are affected are taken care of. One way of doing this is through the CDCs, as mentioned by quite a few Members. I personally will be in favour of providing more funds to the CDCs. But, again, this depends on the Ministries concerned. Remember that I am talking here as Chairman of the CSC.

    A few speakers, including the last Member to speak, Mr Sin Boon Ann, have been quite critical of the Government-linked companies. I think some of the comments are valid. Some of the GLCs have, in fact, strayed from their core business. That is why the CSC has come out with this recommendation that they should focus on one area. Even the big companies, like Sony and others have come to realise that they have gone into too many areas. They have gone into movies. They have gone into what-have-you and realise that they have to go back and concentrate on areas which they know well, because there is only so much managerial resource. If you spread your management too thinly, then you cannot

Column: 1619

look after the business properly. So the recommendation of the Committee is that the GLCs should refocus and spearhead our efforts into particular areas and, hopefully, they will be able to lead us in our regionalisation drive as well by bringing along the supporting industries and the others. This is an area which, I believe, Temasek Holdings will be looking carefully into.

    The other area I want to touch on briefly is this long-term vision which Members have supported generally. It is an ambitious but, I believe, achievable vision. But it may take longer than 10 years, I agree. Some Members have said that, in fact, this vision is not entirely new and that is also true. Because we have been going on this track all this while and it goes to show that we are on the right track. I remember that, as far back as 1969, not quite 1969 when I joined EDB, but early 1970s, we were already talking of having brain services, promoting brain service industries. So here, we are back to knowledge industries. We have done a lot since then, the kind of manufacturing that we have gone into, wafer fabrication and all that. We have moved into more knowledge and skill-intensive areas, and that is the correct thrust. It is good for us that we maintain this core of manufacturing. I think Hong Kong has come to realise too late. They are hollowed out. They pushed all this to Shenzhen and elsewhere and even though that is part of China, and they are part of China, they have to compete very hard. And now, what is the role for Hong Kong? That is their worry. And that is why the CSC recommended that we should have both manufacturing and services. In fact, the two are complementary. A lot of the services actually are for the manufacturing, whether it is transportation, logistics or financing. So our aim should be to promote high value-added services and manufacturing together.

    One of the key areas that we will have to strive for is to try and develop technopreneurship. This is the idea of a knowledge economy and we are studying, of course, Silicon Valley, looking at how Taiwan does it, how Israel does it. We are investing a lot of money in R&D. The question is: can

Column: 1620

we realise more returns from that? It is good to build up capabilities and it is very important. But, eventually, we must be able to have our own start-up companies, float them and develop our own indigenous companies.

    Here, I would like to mention that the Government is taking this effort very seriously. The Government has decided to set up a committee chaired by DPM Dr Tony Tan. There is a committee known as Technopreneur 21 Ministerial Committee (T21MC) - we have all these acronyms nowadays - chaired by DPM Dr Tony Tan and there will be three other Ministers on this Committee. My colleague, BG George Yeo, will be Deputy Chairman and the others will be Mr Lim Hng Kiang and RAdm Teo Chee Hean. So you can see that it is a very high-powered Committee. The intention is to give this area a big push because I think this area of the future, it has come with the development of computers, with the development of IT. We have Singapore One. We are trying to make more use of it. I think we are really at the cutting edge. The question is whether we have the talent. Can we attract more people to come here? Can we link up with other countries and achieve synergies?

    IT is one big area. The other area will be in the life sciences. Nowadays, it is possible for researchers to screen drugs, millions of drugs in a short period of time. So now with all these new areas of cloning, cloning of heart tissue and so on, these will be new growth industries of the future. I realise there will be a lot of ethical problems as well. These are growth industries and we should not miss out on them.

    So the investment in R&D, the setting-up of Science Parks, setting-up of Incubator Units, providing support to the technopreneurs who are usually more scientifically inclined rather than businessmen, holding their hands in business, and so on. These are things that we are putting in place. And with Dr Tony Tan and BG George Yeo who are very keen in this area, I am sure we will see some progress in this sector.

I cannot answer all the points today.
